{"label":"Info On Learning", "category":"TextLabels_Size5", "size":"350 30", "key":55, "location":"-1130 -1010"},
{"label":"[C]ontinuous / [D]iscrete", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 30", "key":62, "location":"-1760 -490"},
{"label":"- [C] Classification of cups
- [C] Feeling/classification of temperature/color
- [D] Preparation of coffee
- [D] Sorting objects into containers (in general)", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":66, "location":"-1650 -320", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Touring-Complete", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 30", "key":73, "location":"-2870 -100"},
{"label":"- A Neural Network is not Touring-Complete
. You can't train a neural network to compute the n-th digit of pi
. But you can write a computer program for that
- Is our brain Touring-Complete?
- Does Intelligence need TC?
- If intelligence is not TC, then it is Intelligence-Complete
. - So, what is IC?
. - What are the characteristics of non IC?
. - A computer program is considered non IC, why?
- A CPU is Touring-Complete
- What are the advantage/disadvantage in being TC?", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":77, "location":"-2720 240", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"How far GTP-3 goes with Intelligence?", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 30", "key":79, "location":"-1100 80"},
{"label":"- It has access to a huge amount of knowledge
- It has learned a lot of knowledge
- It is able to discuss about acquired knowledge
- It is able to use knowledge to create articles, stories, ...
- Does it understand the knowledge it uses?
. - Probably no
. - What is characteristic of a system that understand vs a 
.    system that do not understand?
. - Do human being understand the knowledge they handle?
.   - What are signs of understanding or not understanding?", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":81, "location":"-1170 400", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"- There are about 7000 languages in the world
- But many more languages exists: monkey language, whale language, ...
- What is the contribution of language to our intelligence?
- Human language/intelligence is superior. Is our complex language the enabler?", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":83, "location":"-30 1170", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Neural Networks can be seen as Finite State Machines", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 30", "key":85, "location":"-2260 910"},
{"label":"- Neural Networks can be seen as FSM
- CPU are also FSM
- What is the difference?
- At which point a Neural Network lose its advantage over a CPU
- At which point a CPU loses its advantage over a Neural Network?
.
- Is our brain a big-Finite State Machine?
. - Why yes? Why no?
- Is our procedural learning based on FSM?
. - It is discrete, algorithmic, procedural, state-based, ...
. - What are our advantages in manipulating continuous domains 
.   and discrete domains (find some good example of both)", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":87, "location":"-2390 1270", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"References", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 30", "key":89, "location":"-5710 -1020"},
{"label":"1) F.Chollet, "Intelligence and Generalisation", https://youtu.be/J0p_thJJnoo
2) L.Boroditsky, "How language shapes the way we think", https://youtu.be/RKK7wGAYP6k
3) D.C.Dennett, "The Role of Language in Intelligence", http://cogprints.org/192/1/rolelang.htm
4) C.Stangor, J.Walinga, "Introduction to Psychology â€“ 1st Canadian Edition", BCcampus, 17.10.2014", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":91, "location":"-5660 -780", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"What is the role of Language in Intelligence", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":94, "location":"-70 1000"},
{"label":"Intelligence vs Wisdom", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":78, "location":"-380 1680"},
{"label":"- Is intelligence really the best target to follow?
. - Intelligence allowed us to:
.   v Build houses
.   v Fly around the world (through airplanes, ...)
.   v Keep warm/cool with inverse relation to weather
.   v Compute and automate through computers
.   x Fight with one and another (war, ...)
.   x Make people suffer and force them to a miserable life
.   x Accumulate wealth in face of huge disparities
.   x Exploit our planet to excessive extent
- How about targeting to wisdom?
.  - How wisdom differ from intelligence?
.  - How a wise GTP-3 would differ from the current GTP-3?
.  - Is it possible to build a Wise System instead an Intelligent System?
.  - What if more useful to the life on earth: intelligent or wisdom?", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":80, "location":"-190 2120", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Intelligence and Free Will", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":86, "location":"900 -60"},
{"label":"- In considering ourself intelligent, do we have free will on that?
- If we consider we have free will, ...
- If we don't have free will, can we really consider ourself intelligent
. or are we just following "the program"", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":88, "location":"940 110", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Yin&Yang", "category":"Pictures_Basic", "size":"278 302", "isFile":true, "fileTypeName":"Image", "fileType":"image/png", "fileURL":"fileServer/YinYang.png", "key":76, "location":"-1650 -850"},
{"label":"Conscious and unconscious Learning", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":90, "location":"-2740 1860"},
{"label":"- Statistical learning (DNN) is mostly unconscious learning?
- Expert systems are mostly conscious learning?
.
1) Learning from the input/output data leads to unconscious learning
.   here the algorithmical model behind the data is implicit and rough
.   here you need a hight amount of data in relation to the accuracy of
.   the function you want to learn
.   here the learning method provide good generalisation stills
2) Learning from the algorithmic process leads to conscious learning
.   here the algorithmical model is precise and explicit
.   here few data is sufficient for expressing the problem space
.   here the precision of the algorithm imply a low generalisation skills
- Neural networks are more suitable for (1) and relatively bad for (2)
- State machines are more suitable for (2) and relatively bad for (1)", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":92, "location":"-2670 2280", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Building Intelligent Systems", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":96, "location":"-1760 2850"},
{"label":"- How to implement intelligence? Are you Intelligent?
- How to implement learning? How often are you experiencing learning?", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":97, "location":"-1690 2980", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Preprogrammed vs Programmable", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":100, "location":"1790 590"},
{"label":"- In nature we can observe a particular difference between animals and humans
- Baby animal exhibits a strong repertory of preprogrammed skills from birth
- Human baby exhibits, in comparison, a very limited set of skills at birth
- Comparing the two spices, it emerge that animals shows a stronger set of
. preprogrammed skill, compared to humans, with limited increase in their life
- On the same line, humans exhibit a wider set of skill, learned along their life
- Along this perspective, preprogrammed skills are associated to a limited
. degree of intelligence. While the flexible and plastic structure of humans,
. exhibit the highest level of "intelligence" in nature
.
- In the computer world we can observe a particular difference between 
. a Lotus Notes application and a GTP-3 system
- Lotus Notes exhibits a strong repertory of preprogrammed skills from source code
- GTP-3 exhibits, in comparison, a very limited set of kills from source code
- Comparing the two, we tend to consider GTP-3 a more intelligent entity, compared
. to a preprogrammed Lotus Notes", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":101, "location":"1850 1070", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Intelligence", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":104, "location":"340 -900"},
{"label":"- There are several types of intelligence
. - Motoric intelligence
. - Emotional intelligence
. - Linguistic intelligence
. - Spatial intelligence
. - Logical intelligence
. - ...
With intelligence we refer here to (4): 
. the ability to think, to learn from experience, 
. to solve problems, and to adapt to new situations", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":105, "location":"500 -570", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Fluid Intelligence vs Express Intelligence", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":108, "location":"2240 -930"},
{"label":"- Intrinsic Intelligence: finding and implementing original solutions
- Extrinsic Intelligence: using solutions from others
- II shows our capability of original thinking
- EI shows our capability of knowledge or reuse from others
- Not showing II and EI -> ...what does it imply?", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":109, "location":"2280 -740", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Intrinsic Intelligence vs Extrinsic Intelligence", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":111, "location":"2240 -1030"},
{"label":"On Problem Solving", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":114, "location":"3030 -230"},
{"label":"- One of the characteristic of intelligence is problem solving
- We often solve problems not just with our mind, but with external support
- We often don't have the full capacity to imagine a solution to the level
. of details that a working solution needs
- We often have an approximated idea that gets refined/corrected/concretised
. with the usage of external tools
- The classic saying "a plan is just a plan" is one of the examples underling that
- Anyone using a computer knows that part of the realisation of a software entity
. is solved by the computer itself, demonstrating us how our ideas actually works", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":115, "location":"3160 60", "textAlign":"left"},
{"label":"Learning is as important as Teaching", "category":"TextLabels_Size4", "size":"250 32", "key":93, "location":"1600 1790"},
{"label":"- We are very often looking at  AI from the learning aspects
- We should consider a similar attention on the teaching side
. - Conceiving more natural teaching scenarios
. - Using teaching system closer to real teaching scenarios
. - Avoiding to prepare and package data with scripts and 
.   processes that are little accessible for humans", "category":"TextLabels_Size3", "size":"150 30", "key":95, "location":"1700 2000", "textAlign":"left"},
